source.322e1d34:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt  # importing library

# directly display graphs etc. 
%matplotlib inline
source.533e8ff7:
# plotting using matplotlib
# as we are using matplotlib inline, there's no need to write
# plt.show() to see the figure it will print it directly.

plt.scatter(x,y,c='r')  # x and y are axis and c is for color
plt.xlabel('X axis')  # label of x axis
plt.ylabel('Y axis')  # label of y axis
plt.title('2D Graph')  # title of graph
plt.savefig('2D.jpg')  # saving figure as a jpg file
source.a2e366be:
# using plot function
# we can use any plot mentioned below

plt.plot(x,y,'r--')  # r-- for red colored dashed line
# plt.plot(x,y,'r')  # r is for red color
# plt.plot(x,y,'ro')  # ro is for dotted line
# plt.plot(x,y,'ro--')  # ro-- is for dotted and dashed line
source.d34b5e89:
# linestyle is the another way to select line style

plt.plot(x,y,'g*', linestyle = 'dashed', linewidth = 2, markersize = 12)
plt.xlabel('X axis')
plt.ylabel('Y axis')
plt.title('Graph')
source.37e92edd:
# subplot

plt.subplot(2,2,1)  # 2,2 are rows and columns and 1 indicates 1st position
plt.plot(x,y,'r--')
plt.subplot(2,2,2)  # 2 indicates 2nd position
plt.plot(x,y,'b*--')
plt.subplot(2,2,3)  # 3 indicates 3rd position
plt.plot(x,y,'go--')
plt.subplot(2,2,4)  # 4 indicates 4th position
plt.plot(x,y,'y-')
plt.savefig('subplot.jpg')  # saving as jpg
source.d2e66c64:
# we can do multiple mathematical oprations and plot it

x = np.arange(0, 4*np.pi, 0.1)  # np.pi is 3.14 and 0.1 is step size
y = np.sin(x)
plt.title('sine wave')
plt.plot(x,y,'g--')  # if we don't use color and line type the default will be blue with solid line
source.90143f0c:
# plotting sine and cosine both

x = np.arange(0, 6*np.pi, 0.1)
y_sin = np.sin(x)
y_cos = np.cos(x)

# using subplot now

plt.subplot(2,1,1)
plt.title('Sine Wave')
plt.plot(x,y_sin,'r--')

plt.subplot(2,1,2)
plt.title('Cosine Wave')
plt.plot(x,y_cos,'g--')
plt.tight_layout(pad = 1.0)  # used to create spacing between plots
source.ab7420c8:
x = [2,8,10]
y = [11,16,9]

x2 = [3,9,11]
y2 = [6,15,7]
plt.bar(x,y)
plt.bar(x2,y2,color = 'g')
plt.title('Bar graph')
plt.xlabel('X axis')
plt.ylabel('Y axis')
source.983ab6e7:
# Histograms are used to identify the desity of a value between a particular
# range in a dataset.

a = np.array([22,10,45,32,4,6,23,65,0,9,23,32,12,56])  # sample data

plt.hist(a, bins = 20)  # bins is used to divide x axis into parts by
                        # default it is set to bins = 10.
plt.title('Histogram')
source.c43ed46e:
# here np.random.normal gives array of mean 0 std. deviation 1,2,3 with 100 values
data = [np.random.normal(0, std, 100) for std in range(1,4)] 

# vert=True means that blocks will be plotted vertcally
# patch_artist fills the color in the blocks
plt.boxplot(data, vert = True, patch_artist = True);
source.f9befffc:
# data
label = 'Python', 'R', 'C++', 'JAVA'
size = [235, 132, 200, 212]  # size will be considerd as percentage
colors = ['lightskyblue', 'yellow', 'green', 'red']
explode = (0.1, 0, 0, 0)  # explode is how far a slice is pulled from the chart

plt.pie(size, explode = explode, labels = label, colors = colors, 
        autopct = '%1.1f%%', shadow = True);
source.aeda4924:
# This is a dataset from a restraunt, it shows that on the basis of total bill
# how much tip a person gave. So here tip is a dependent feature
# Sex, Smoker, Day, Time and Size are independent feature.

df = sns.load_dataset("tips")  # loading in-built dataset in seaborn library
df.head()
source.c61bc99b: df.corr()  # correlation is between float and integers only.
source.b81cde0c:
# By passing reg to kind, it will plot a pdf(probablity density function)
# based on the histogram and put a straight line as linear regression

sns.jointplot(x='tip', y='total_bill', data=df, kind='reg')
source.9aa2ae7c:
# It wil show realtion between total_bill, tip and size

sns.pairplot(df)
source.b24b42f6:
# Now these parameters are based on sex 

sns.pairplot(df, hue='sex')
source.4937c84a:
# if we don't want the curve, kde is kernel density estimation

sns.distplot(df['tip'], kde=False, bins = 10)
source.d4041de8:
# we can also change the axis

sns.countplot(y='day', data = df)
source.9cbcd221:

## Dist plot
Dist plot helps us to check the distribution of the columns feature
source.224c3d89:
## Correalation with heat map
It uses colored cells. Typically in a monochromatic scae, to show 2D correlation matrix(table) between two discrete dimensions or event types. It is crucial in feature selection
source.a630307d:
## Violin Plot
It helps us tp see both the distribution of data in terms of kernel density estimation and the box plot
source.65a9658f:
## JoinPlot
A join plot allows to study the relationship between 2 numeric variables. The central chart display their correlation. It is usually a scatter plot, 2D histogram or a 2D density plot
